instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no power.

It wasen't powering on, and It was pulling 20V from ampmetter, and 0.80amp, had no USB activity and CPU was hot, but when i start measuring the rails, <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> was missing, and after that it started to pull only 5V from ampmetter without no explanation.

<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL>/2 seams to be ok, because I have 0.550 on diode reading. Shall i replace <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: What is diode mode reading at <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi, 

it's shorted. 0.001 in diode and 0.1 ohm to ground

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Try voltage injection.

For next time, do not waste time checking a powe railr which is present for sure; confirmed by another voltage, than can't appear other way!!!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Tks for the tip.
What seams to get hot is the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. Does it makes sense? Shall I replace it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
First remove it and check if short disappeared from <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>.
Let the board cools down first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
HI,
After removing <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> the short on  <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>  was gone, and so I replaced <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. However, now I get 20.5V from ampmetter, and only 0.21A.
The mac won't power on, and its not responding to the keyboard commands

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Do you get voltage on big coils?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
CPU gets hot

L7670 = 0.019V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V

L7690 = 3.3V
L8410 = 0.129V
L7030 = 9.45V
L7430 = 0V
L7410 = 0V
L7230 = 0V
L7210 = 0V
L7290 = 0V

As <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is missing, can it be a bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
If you get 20V on USB-C input, shouldn't be <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue.
CPU is probably bad, if gets hot in this state.
